properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
  • High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake.

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 31/03/2024 05:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BLUE GREEN ALGAE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Lake Bolac
Issue Date: Tuesday 23 January 2024, 03:14 pm
Next Update: Sunday 31 March 2024, 05:20 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32563/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
- High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 



Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 
You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Barwon River.

  • High levels of Blue Green Algae have been detected in the river between Baum’s Weir and Lower Breakwater.
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the river or cooler conditions slow the algae.  
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality.
You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Barwon River.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Corangamite CMA website for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the river.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue green algae.
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 15/03/2024 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobacteria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Amphitheatre, Avoca, Bayindeen, Beaufort, Ben Nevis, Buangor East, Chute, Elmhurst, Eurambeen, Eversley, Glenlogie, Glenpatrick, Green Hill Creek, Langi Kal Kal, Lexton, Main Lead, Mount Cole, Mount Lonarch, Nowhere Creek, Raglan, Rosyth, Trawalla, Waterloo, Brewster, Buangor, Ercildoune, Glenbrae, Glenlofty, Lamplough, Middle Creek, Mount Cole Creek, Percydale, Warrak, Warrenmang
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Amphitheatre, Avoca, Bayindeen, Beaufort, Ben Nevis, Brewster, Buangor, Buangor East, Chute, Elmhurst, Ercildoune, Eurambeen, Eversley, Glenbrae, Glenlofty, Glenlogie, Glenpatrick, Green Hill Creek, Lamplough, Langi Kal Kal, Lexton, Main Lead, Middle Creek, Mount Cole, Mount Cole Creek, Mount Lonarch, Nowhere Creek, Percydale, Raglan, Rosyth, Trawalla, Warrak, Warrenmang, Waterloo. 

  • The bushfire at Bayindeen-Rocky Road is under control.
  • Firefighters continue to black out hot spots within the burnt area. 
  • Heavy machinery and fire vehicles are still operating, assessing and treating hazardous trees along local roads.
  • Smoke may still be visible around the general fire area.
  • The message replaced the Community Information from Wednesday 6 March at 3:32pm.
State Forest Closures:
Access is prohibited to all areas of Mount Cole/Beeripmo and Mount Lonarch/Berumgower State Forests until 30 April 2024.

Mt Buangor State Park is closed until further notice.  This includes Middle Creek, Ferntree and Bailes Camping Areas and all walking tracks.

These forests have been made Public Safety Zones under the Safety on Public Land Act 2004 for the maintenance of public safety and for fire recovery operations.

A map showing the public safety zone is held at the Ballarat office and at the Department’s head office at 8 Nicholson Street, East Melbourne, Victoria 3002. The map is also available on the following web site: www.ffm.vic.gov.au/ permits-and-regulations/closures-of-parks-and-forests
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required however you must remain diligent and keep informed due to the current warm weather and dry landscape 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 17/03/2024 04:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Water tanks and fire  
  •  If your area is affected by bushfires, your water tank could be contaminated from debris, ash, fire retardants or dead animals. 
  • You should disconnect the downpipes to your tanks as soon as there is a bushfire risk. Only reconnect the downpipes when the roof has been cleaned. 
  • If your water looks, smells or tastes unusual, then it is likely to be contaminated. Do not use the water for drinking or food preparation, and do not give it to animals.
  • Boiling water does not remove fire retardants or other chemicals from your water. 
  • If the water in your tank has not been contaminated, the water should be safe to use. If your water tank has been contaminated please contact councils environmental health officer for advice prior to re-using it for drinking purposes. 
  •  You can contact your local council for help. For more information visit Bushfires and private drinking water
Fences and control lines after bushfire
For information regarding damaged fencing as a result of the fire or fire suppression activities ring 136186 or visit the website:Fences and Control Lines after bushfire

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Issue Date: Sunday 10 March 2024, 11:28 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/33332/moreinfo

- Firefighters continue to black out hot spots within the burnt area.

- The message replaced the Community Information from Wednesday 6 March at 3:32pm.

Access is prohibited to all areas of Mount Cole/Beeripmo and Mount Lonarch/Berumgower State Forests until 30 April 2024.

Mt Buangor State Park is closed until further notice.  This includes Middle Creek, Ferntree and Bailes Camping Areas and all walking tracks. 

These forests have been made Public Safety Zones under the Safety on Public Land Act 2004 for the maintenance of public safety and for fire recovery operations.

A map showing the public safety zone is held at the Ballarat office and at the Department’s head office at 8 Nicholson Street, East Melbourne, Victoria 3002. The map is also available on the following web site: www.ffm.vic.gov.au/ permits-and-regulations/closures-of-parks-and-forests

There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required however you must remain diligent and keep informed due to the current warm weather and dry landscape

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Condah, Myamyn, Wallacedale, Wallacedale North.

  • There is a small bushfire near the Henty Highway, fleece road intersection in Condah that is under control.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • Firefighters are patrolling this fire.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 11/03/2024 04:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for those most at risk of extreme heat exposure to prepare for forecast heatwave conditions.

Bureau of Meteorology have issued low-intensity heatwave for Mallee, Northern Country and North East districts and severe-intensity heatwave in Wimmera, East Gippsland, West and South Gippsland, Central, North Central and South West Districts.
  • Heatwave conditions have been forecast for Saturday through to Monday. 
  • Those more at-risk include people over the age of 65, babies and young children, pregnant women, people with acute or chronic health problems and people who are socially isolated.
  • Maximum temperatures increasing to the high 30's to low 40's on Saturday. Overnight temperatures will remain in the 20s overnight.

Protect your health: 
  • Heat can make anyone sick. 
  • Heat can cause serious and potentially fatal health problems such as heat exhaustion and heatstroke, trigger sudden events like heart attack or stroke, or worsen existing medical conditions like kidney or lung disease.
Prepare now to stay safe in the heat. Be aware of the risk of heat-related health problem and plan ahead to keep yourself and others safe.   
What you should do:
  • Stay cool on hot days: Use an air conditioner or a fan, wear light and loose clothing, or splash or spray cool water onto your skin.
  • Keep hydrated: Always take a drink bottle with you. 
  • Check in with family, friends and neighbours: Let people know you are OK or check in on those at increased risk including people over the age of 65, young children and babies, pregnant women, people with acute or chronic health problems and people who are socially isolated.
  • Plan ahead: Cancel or reschedule activities for a cooler time of the day and check the weather forecast regularly. 
  • Hot cars kill: Never leave kids, adults or pets in cars. The temperature inside a parked car can double within minutes.
  • Care for your pets: Heat can stress pets. Provide cool, clean water and shade for your pets and animals.
Know the symptoms of heat-related health problems and monitor your health. 
Plan ahead and keep up to date with weather forecasts. To find out more information visit: https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/extreme-heat.
Impacts in your Area:
  • If you are travelling or attending major events this long weekend, you could be facing extreme heat conditions.
This message was issued by Emergency Management Commissioner. 

The next update is expected by 10/03/2024 09:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#survivetheheat)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 

  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - EXTREME HEAT  - Prepare Now
Incident Location: State of Victoria
Issue Date: Friday 08 March 2024, 05:47 pm
Next Update: Sunday 10 March 2024, 09:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/33324/moreinfo

This Community Information message is being issued for those most at risk of extreme heat exposure to prepare for forecast heatwave conditions.

Bureau of Meteorology have issued low-intensity heatwave for Mallee, Northern Country and North East districts and severe-intensity heatwave in Wimmera, East Gippsland, West and South Gippsland, Central, North Central and South West Districts.
- Heatwave conditions have been forecast for Saturday through to Monday. 
- Those more at-risk include people over the age of 65, babies and young children, pregnant women, people with acute or chronic health problems and people who are socially isolated.
- Maximum temperatures increasing to the high 30's to low 40's on Saturday. Overnight temperatures will remain in the 20s overnight.


Protect your health: 
- Heat can make anyone sick. 
- Heat can cause serious and potentially fatal health problems such as heat exhaustion and heatstroke, trigger sudden events like heart attack or stroke, or worsen existing medical conditions like kidney or lung disease. 


Prepare now to stay safe in the heat. Be aware of the risk of heat-related health problem and plan ahead to keep yourself and others safe.
